newsitem.title: USA: Czech import deposit barrier to US exports-attache.
newsitem.headline: Czech import deposit barrier to US exports-attache.

text.p: The Czech Republic's new import deposit will constitute a "serious barrier" to U.S. agricultural exports to that country, particularly high-value and specialty goods, a U.S. agricultural attache said.

"Dollar value of the impact cannot yet be assessed but the regulation will surely have a particularly severe dampening effect on imports of high-value and specialty foods, which tend to be shipped in truck- and container lots, as well as imports of livestock genetics," the attache said in a report.
The report, dated April 24, was released here Tuesday. Attache reports are not official USDA data.

Earlier this month, the Czech government said it would impose a requirement on importers of consumer and agricultural goods to deposit 20 percent of the value of their shipments in non-interest bearing accounts for 180 days.
The U.S. attache said small companies that handle these items are less able to absorb the extra expense of tying up 20 percent of working capital in non-bearing escrow accounts.
U.S. citrus products will remain unaffected by the regulation, the attache said.
